Let \(p\) be a prime number. \(p^a\) exactly divides the integer \(n\) if \({p^a}|n\) but \({p^{a+1} \nmid n}\). We represent this as \( p^a ∥ n\).
Assume \(p^a ∥ m\) and \(p^b ∥ n\). What is the maximum power of \(p\) that divides \(m+n\)?

According to the fundamental theorem of arithmetic, \(m\) can be represented as:

$$ m = {p_1}^{k_1} * {p_2}^{k_2} * \ldots $$

But we are only interested in the \(p\) in question:

$$ m = p^a * \ldots $$

As for \(n\):

$$ n = p^b * \ldots $$

If \(m+n\), then:

$$\begin{align} m+n &= (p^a * \ldots) + (p^b * \ldots) \\ &= p ^{\min \{ a, b \}} * ((\ldots) + ( \ldots)) \end{align}$$

Therefore, \(p ^{\min \{ a, b \}}\) exactly divides \(m+n\).
Assume \(p^a ∥ m\) and \(p^b ∥ n\). What is the maximum power of \(p\) that divides \(mn\)?

According to the fundamental theorem of arithmetic, \(m\) can be represented as:

$$ m = {p_1}^{k_1} * {p_2}^{k_2} * \ldots $$

But we are only interested in the \(p\) in question:

$$ m = p^a * \ldots $$

As for \(n\):

$$ n = p^b * \ldots $$

If \(mn\), then:

$$\begin{align} mn &= (p^a * \ldots) * (p^b * \ldots) \\ &= p ^{a + b} * ((\ldots) + ( \ldots)) \end{align}$$

Therefore, \(p ^{a + b}\) exactly divides \(mn\).
Assume \(p^a ∥ m\) and \(p^b ∥ n\). What is the maximum power of \(p\) that divides \(m^n\)?

According to the fundamental theorem of arithmetic, \(m\) can be represented as:

$$ m = {p_1}^{k_1} * {p_2}^{k_2} * \ldots $$

But we are only interested in the \(p\) in question:

$$ m = p^a * \ldots $$

As for \(n\):

$$ n = p^b * \ldots $$

If \(m^n\), then:

$$\begin{align} m^n &= (p^a * \ldots) ^ (p^b * \ldots) \\ &= p ^{a p^b} * ((\ldots) + ( \ldots)) \end{align}$$

Therefore, \(p ^{a p^b}\) exactly divides \(m^n\).
